Comment: However, se 'this' can occasionally function as a definite article.
In spoken language, ikš may sometimes be found in such a usage.
For nominal conjunction tehre is un or ja, whereas for comitative there is the instrumental case.
The nominative and genitive tend to show syncretism.
There is a prefix but it is not fully productive or predictable
Forms of äb vs. forms of alā
Sa äd Ma, Ta, Ne äb
Reduplication is not a productive process in Livonian.
The elative form can be used: Jǭņ um mi’nstõ jo nūoŗ
In Livonian, it is also common to use the preposition "jo", e.g. jo vanā 'older'
There is istinction in the 2nd person forms.
In Livonian, there is no synthetic impersonal marker; the passive is analytical formed by the auxiliary sǭdõ 'to get; become'.
There are some examples of elative-marked NPs
The independent reflexive pronoun is ī’ž : eņtš
No, the pronoun is bipartite: ī’dtuoiz (= one + other)
In Livonian, in addition to jarā verbal prefixes (e.g. no- etc.) are used as well.
